[[File:Per-Olof Åstrand.jpg|thumb|Åstrand in ''[[Hylands hörna]]'', 1963]] '''Per-Olof Åstrand''' (21 October 1922 – 2 January 2015)<ref>http://traningslara.se/tva-av-sveriges-framst-idrottsforskare-har-gatt-bort/</ref><ref>[http://exxentric.com/per-olof-astrand-remembered/ Per-Olof Åstrand Remembered: My First Inspiration for Applied Sport Science]</ref> was a [[Swedes|Swedish]] [[professor]] of [[physiology]] at the Royal Gymnastic Central Institute (GCI/GIH) in Stockholm 1970–1977, and 1977–1988 at the [[Karolinska Institute]] in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]], and a member of the [[Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institutet]] (1977–1988). Åstrand is considered a "pioneer",<ref name=gih/> "legend"<ref name=lt>[http://www.lakartidningen.se/Functions/OldArticleView.aspx?articleId=6880 Läkartidningen] 2007</ref> and one of the "founding fathers" of modern [[exercise physiology]].<ref name=topend>[http://www.topendsports.com/testing/history-astrand.htm Per-Olof Åstrand, Topendsports]</ref>
Åstrand graduated from the Royal Gymnastic Central Institute (GCI/GIH) in Stockholm, Sweden, now called [[Gymnastik- och idrottshögskolan|Swedish School of Sport and Health Sciences, GIH]] in 1946. Then he was already amanuensis at its Department of Physiology, where he started his thesis work. In 1952 he defended his thesis and got his [[Ph.D.]] at the medical school at the Karolinska Institute, since GCI/GIH in those days did not have such rights as a university college. He became a professor in physiology at GCI/GIH in 1970.<ref name=gih/><ref name=topend/> Åstrand had over 200 research publications and his areas of research included work physiology and the human [[circulatory system|oxygen transporting system]], [[Outline of academic disciplines#Human physical performance and recreation|physical performance]], [[health and fitness]], [[preventive medicine]], and [[Physical therapy|rehabilitation]].<ref name=topend/>
Åstrand is known for developing the [[Submaximal performance testing|Åstrand-Ryhming Cycle Ergometer Test]] in 1954 in collaboration with his future wife Irma Ryhming. His book ''Textbook of Work Physiology'' has been translated to eight languages.<ref name=gih>[http://www.gih.se/OM-GIH/Aktuellt/Kalendarium/Arkiv/P-O-Astrand-fyller-90ar/ Swedish School of Sport and Health Sciences]</ref>
Per-Olof Åstrand was [[Doctor Honoris Causa]] at eight universities. He was also an honorary member of the [[American College of Cardiology]], the [[Royal Australasian College of Physicians]] and the [[American College of Sports Medicine]].<ref name=lt/><ref name=topend/> In 2000 Åstrand was awarded the first Lifetime Achievement Award in exercise physiology by the [[American Society of Exercise Physiologists]] (ASEP).<ref>[http://www.asep.org/asep/asep/Astrand.html ASEP.org]</ref>
== See also ==

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Saparmurat Turkmenbashi Olympic Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:Saparmurat Turkmenbashi Olympic Stadium.jpg|300px]] | location = [[Ashgabat]], [[Turkmenistan]] | coordinates = | opened = 2003 | renovated = 2013–2017 | owner = | record_attendance = {{formatnum:30000}} ([[Turkmenistan]] v [[Hong Kong]], [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC Second Round|18 November 2007]])[http://www.goal.com/en-gh/match/turkmenistan-vs-hong-kong/527396/lineups Turkmenistan 3 – 0 Hong Kong] | operator = | surface = | general_contractor = Mensel JV Consulting & Contracting Inc.[http://www.turkmenistan.ru/?page_id=9&lang_id=ru&elem_id=726&type=event&sort=date_desc][http://www.if-group.de/de/membran/stadien/olympia-stadium-ashkhabat.html Olympia Stadion Ashkhabat]
Renovation by [[Polimeks]].[http://stadiumdb.com/designs/tkm/ashgabat_olympic_stadium Ashgabat Olympic Stadium] | closed = | demolished = | construction_cost = | architect = [[AFL Architects]] / [[Arup Group|Arup]] | tenants = [[Turkmenistan national football team]][https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=257787/match=300159196/report.html Turkmenistan - Indonesia] | seating_capacity = 45,000 }} '''Saparmurat Turkmenbashi Olympic Stadium''' ({{lang-tk|Saparmyrat Türkmenbaşy adyndaky Olimpiýa Stadiony}}) was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Ashgabat]], [[Turkmenistan]], that stood on the site now occupied by the New Olympic Stadium, which is being built from 2013 until 2017.[http://stadiumdb.com/news/2015/04/new_design_olympic_stadium_resembling_a_horse New design: Olympic Stadium resembling… a horse] ==Overview== The stadium holds 30,000 people and was built in 2003. Despite the use of the name "[[Olympic Stadium]]" the facility was neither built as part of a bid to host the [[Olympic Games]], nor has it been used in such games. In 2007 the Turkmen government decided to reconstruct the stadium and to enlarge it. The new arena will hold up to 45,000 people.[http://tourism-sport.gov.tm/sport.php Infos on tourism-sport.gov.tm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090529012845/http://www.tourism-sport.gov.tm/sport.php |date=2009-05-29 }} The stadium closed in 2012, and was partially demolished in 2013 for [[redevelopment]].[http://www.azathabar.org/content/article/25206186.html Olimpiýa taýýarlyk: Çykdajylar we ýerliklilik][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nqKXWtCAY7I "Olympic" stadium is being dismantled in Ashgabat] The most prominent feature of the new renovations is the horse head of "[[Akhal-Teke]]" which resembles the national emblem of the country.{{cite news|url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2017/08/new_stadium_the_600ton_horse_head_in_ashgabat|title=New stadium: The 600-ton horse head in Ashgabat|publisher=StadiumDB|access-date=28 October 2017}} ==Events== It was used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches, but also for musical performances by Turkmen pop stars such as [[Maral Ibragimova]].{{Cite web|url=http://video.mail.ru/mail/geldiska92/_myvideo/305.html?liked=1|title=video of Maral performing at Ashgabat Olympic Stadium|accessdate=2013-01-22}} The renovated stadium was the site of the '''[[2017 Asian Indoor and Martial Arts Games|5th Asian Indoor and Martial Arts Games]]''', which is also counted as the 5th Asian Indoor Games. The opening and closing ceremonies for the games were held in [[Ashgabat]], [[Turkmenistan]] on 17th and 27th September 2017.{{cite web |url=http://www.ocasia.org/News/IndexNewsRM.aspx?WKegervtea1xpk0X4VisIg== |title=OCA signs host agreement with Turkmenistan |date=19 December 2010}} ==See also== *[[Ashgabat Stadium]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Ashgabat Olympic Stadium}} *[http://www.afl-uk.com/projects/ashgabat-stadium-turkmenistan New Project] {{Ashgabat}} {{coord|37|54|15.93|N|58|22|37.51|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Turkmenistan]] [[Category:Sports venues in Ashgabat]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Turkmenistan]] [[Category:National stadiums|Turkmenistan]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Turkmenistan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Turkmenistan]] {{Turkmenistan-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Tyler Cup''' was a football competition played between soccer clubs in the North and Republic of Ireland played between 1978 and 1980. It was similar to the earlier [[Blaxnit Cup]], [[North-South Cup]], [[Dublin and Belfast Intercity Cup]] or the present day [[Setanta Sports Cup]]. ==Tyler Cup results== The finals were played on a two-leg basis. [http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/alliercuphist.html All Ireland Football Competitions] {| class="wikitable" border=1 |-bgcolor=#D0E7FF !Season !Winner !Aggregate
score !Runner-up |- |1978 |{{flagicon|IRL}}[[Shamrock Rovers FC|Shamrock Rovers]] [http://www.shamrockrovers.ie/about/history Shamrock Rovers Club History website] |align="center"|1-0 |{{flagicon|IRL}}[[Finn Harps]] |- |1979 |{{flagicon|IRL}}[[Athlone Town A.F.C.|Athlone Town]] |align="center"|3-2 |{{flagicon|IRL}}[[Drogheda United]] |- |1980 |{{flagicon|NIR}}[[Linfield F.C.|Linfield]] |align="center"|2-1 |{{flagicon|IRL}}[[Athlone Town A.F.C.|Athlone Town]] |} ==External links== * [http://www.glenniewebdesign.com/IFCP/home.online.no/_smogols/ifcp/archive/allirelandarchive/crossbordercompetitions.html Irish Football Club Project Archive on All-Ireland Competitions] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Association football cup competitions in Ireland}} [[Category:Defunct all-Ireland association football cup competitions]] [[Category:1978–79 in Republic of Ireland football]] [[Category:1979–80 in Republic of Ireland football]] [[Category:1980–81 in Republic of Ireland football]] [[Category:1978–79 in Northern Ireland football]] [[Category:1979–80 in Northern Ireland football]] [[Category:1980–81 in Northern Ireland football]] {{Ireland-footy-competition-stub}}

{{infobox country at games | NOC = COD | NOCname = Comité Olympique Congolais | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1988 | flagcaption = [[Flag of the Democratic Republic of the Congo|Flag of Zaire]] | oldcode = ZAI | website = | location = [[Seoul]] | competitors = 15 | sports = 3 | flagbearer = [[Dikanda Diba]] | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }}
'''[[Zaire]]''' (now called the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]) competed at the '''[[1988 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea|Korea]].
==Results by event==
===[[Athletics at the 1988 Summer Olympics|Athletics]]=== '''Men's 10000 metres''' * [[Kamana Koji]] :# First Round — did not finish (→ no ranking)
'''Men's Marathon''' * [[Kamana Koji]] — 2:38:34 (→ 73rd place) * [[Kaleka Mutoke]] — 2:55:21 (→ 89th place)
===[[Boxing at the 1988 Summer Olympics|Boxing]]=== '''Men's Bantamweight (– 54 kg)''' * [[Ibibongo Nduita]] :* First Round — Defeated [[Haji Ally]] (TNZ), 3:2 :* Second Round — Lost to [[Katsuyoki Matsushima]] (JPN) 0:5
'''Men's Light Welterweight (– 63.5 kg)''' * [[Kampompo Miango]] :* First Round — Bye :* Second Round — Disqualified for not showing up at morning weigh-in.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bowen|first=Les|title=Biondi Anchors Record Relay Wins Third Gold, Fifth Medal In Leading U.S. To World Mark|url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-09-23/sports/26233125_1_chris-jacobs-hungary-s-tamas-darnyi-troy-dalbey|publisher=[[Philadelphia Daily News]]|date=23 September 1988|accessdate=2 March 2016}}</ref>
'''Men's Light Middleweight (– 71 kg)''' * [[Vaban Banko]] :* First Round — Bye :* Second Round — Lost to [[Segundo Mercado]] (ECU), 0:5
'''Men's Middleweight (– 75 kg)''' * [[Serge Kabongo]] :* First Round — Defeated [[James Iahuat]] (VAN), RSC-1 :* Second Round — Lost to [[Hussain Shah Syed]] (PAK), 0:5
'''Men's Light Heavyweight (– 81 kg)''' * [[Rund Kanika]] :* First Round — Lost to [[Osmond Imadiyi]] (NGR), KO-1
'''Men's Super Heavyweight (+ 91 kg)''' * [[Tshibalabala Kadima]] :* First Round — Lost to [[Andreas Schnieders]] (FRG), RSC-2
==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports]
